metadata.title: The Use of Decision Modelling to Inform Timely Policy Decisions on Cardiac Resource Capacity during the COVID-19 Pandemic.

body_text.text: The cardiac modeling group consisted of a multidisciplinary team of graduate students, clinician-scientists, and academics with expertise in cardiology/cardiac surgery, infectious disease, and advanced decision analytic modeling. We engaged our primary stakeholder, CorHealth Ontario to understand the needs of the type of predictions required to make timely policy decisions. CorHealth Ontario is responsible for providing recommendations to the MOHLTC on the provision of cardiac, vascular and stroke care. The modeling was performed iteratively to contend with the rapid evolution of the pandemic and the model output was assessed at biweekly meetings with stakeholders to inform policy decisions.
body_text.section: Overview of model structure and inputs ::: Introduction

body_text.text: A parallel, open-cohort, dynamic individual-patient-level microsimulation (COvid-19 Resource Estimator, CORE) model to predict hospital resource utilization of COVID-19 patients presenting daily to hospital from the perspective of the Ontario healthcare system was created by researchers and clinicians at the University of Toronto’s Covid-19-MC team.3 An interactive version of the model is publicly available [https://www.covid-19-mc.ca/]. In this model, a daily influx of symptomatic COVID-19 patients (based on patterns of predicted epidemiology at that time) entered the hospital system to compete for a pool of fixed healthcare resources. By running the model over the specified time horizon of the pandemic, this model allowed for the estimation of daily ward, ICU, and ventilators use at the provincial level over the course of the pandemic. Findings from the CORE model were used to set policy and inform technical press briefings by Ontario Health, the MOHLTC and the Ontario Premier’s office.
body_text.section: Overview of model structure and inputs ::: Introduction

body_text.text:
The CORE model was then adapted to include a cardiac submodule (Figure 1
). We chose to examine three areas of cardiovascular medicine with a poor natural history when left untreated: severe symptomatic valvular heart disease requiring open valve surgery or transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR), advanced coronary artery disease requiring revascularization with coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) or percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), and arrhythmia disorders requiring ablation therapy or implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD) device implantation. We did not include heart transplantation, mechanical circulatory support, or cardiac catheterization procedures outside of PCI.
body_text.section: Overview of model structure and inputs ::: Introduction

body_text.text: Our work took place over 3 phases. In the initial “crisis” phase of the pandemic, we examined the impact of increasing number of COVID-19 patients under various epidemiological scenarios (expected scenario, worst case, “Italy scenario”, best case, “South Korea scenario”),3 entering hospitals, requiring the use of cardiac care resources, such as dedicated cardiac ICU and ward beds, and thereby displacing non-COVID-19 cardiac patients. We used epidemiology scenarios from other countries, as that in Ontario was evolving and not known. Nonetheless, pandemic planning was required and could not be delayed till the Ontario epidemiology became apparent. The model estimated unplanned cardiovascular admissions and waitlist mortality for the three modelled cardiovascular disease states based on the published literature.4 The second phase of our model examined the impact of a policy decision to further curtail elective outpatient procedures (April 5th, 2020) on an increasing waitlist as the Ontario epidemiology became apparent. The third and on-going phase of the model is recovery, as the Ontario COVID-19 pandemic is beyond its peak and currently in a plateau. Our work now focusses on the time required to clear the backlog of outpatient cardiac procedures by modeling various scenarios of the healthcare system’s capacity to perform cardiac procedures relative to baseline volume prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. Please see the Supplementary Appendix for further details of methods and the results for each phase.
body_text.section: Overview of model structure and inputs ::: Introduction

body_text.text:
Initial work performed in late March using the CORE model showed that in the worst case COVID-19 transmission scenario (Figure 2
A, Supplementary Table S1), the increasing rate of COVID-19 cases in Ontario raised substantial concerns that the system was at an inflection point, whereby a surge of critically ill patients could overwhelm the acute care system.3 We compared the potential deaths from COVID-19 patients in a hypothetical ICU and ventilator shortage scenario to the potential deaths of elective patients waiting for their cardiac procedures. We showed that the potential number of deaths for patients awaiting their elective cardiac procedures would be orders of magnitude less than those who would die of COVID-19 if there was a depletion of critical care resources (Figure 2B). This led to the urgent release of CorHealth COVID-19 Cardiac Memo #7 on April 4th, 2020 to all cardiac hospital CEOs, reinforcing the need for an immediate cessation in all elective outpatient cardiac procedures and surgeries across Ontario.
body_text.section: 1st phase ::: Findings throughout the different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: Over the following week, as the epidemiology of COVID-19 was better known, it became clear that public health interventions such as physical distancing were effective and Ontario would not follow the worst case transmission scenario (Supplementary Figure S3).3 Under the new epidemiology pattern, our model predicted adequate global and cardiac resources across Ontario to resume selected outpatient procedures. However, our model suggested that across five regions of Ontario, there may not be sufficient resources to resume all elective outpatient cardiac procedures, if cardiac beds remained allocated to COVID-19 patients (Figure 2C). As such, CorHealth COVID-19 Cardiac Memo #8 was released on April 13th and recommended that cardiac centres could resume scheduled outpatient cardiac procedures, restricted to those at highest risk for mortality based on local resource circumstances. We modeled the impact of resumption of cardiac procedures in mid-April at 50% of baseline volumes followed by normal volumes by early May, specifically on the estimated growth in the waitlist (Figure 2D). The above memorandums are briefly summarized in the Supplementary Table S1 along with the COVID-19 epidemiology at the time of memo release.
body_text.section: 2nd Phase ::: Findings throughout the different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: Currently, we are working on estimating the necessary resource capacity and time required to bring the waitlist back to pre-COVID-19 levels. As real-world data is made available, we will be able to validate model outputs against observed outcomes and make iterative improvements to allow for more accurate predictions in the future. This is an important point given the concern for multiple waves of the pandemic in the absence of a vaccine for COVID-19.5 In this first response to the pandemic, the public health mandate was prioritized over other concerns; we recognize that in hindsight, resources were left unused in Ontario. This reinforces the need for prediction models to be improved for the next phase of the pandemic, such that subsequent policy decisions are improved and spillover impacts on non-COVID-19 care is reduced
body_text.section: 3rd Phase ::: Findings throughout the different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: Pandemic planning requires nimble decision making in the face of substantial unknowns. The consequences of delaying decisions until local epidemiology data is known with certainty can be catastrophic, as seen in jurisdictions such as Italy and New York, where the systems were overwhelmed. Modelling provides decision makers with a credible envelope of potential future scenarios, to aid with difficult decisions. The COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario followed this process. Initial worse case scenarios required an immediate and almost complete shift of the healthcare system to care for those critically ill with the virus, at the exclusion of all but the most gravely ill non-COVID-19 patients. Although reasonable in the short term, once local data was known, it required a strategy shift. Understanding the impact of such a policy is crucial in order to understand the cardiac consequences of the decision and to estimate the size of the potential backlog of cardiovascular procedures so that decisions about resumption of activity can be informed. A unique aspect of this model is that COVID-19 patients and cardiovascular patients compete for shared resources. In essence, this explicitly models the fact that policy decisions regarding cardiac patients cannot be made in isolation from the reality of the pandemic and the needs of COVID-19 patients.
body_text.section: Summary of modeling implications for policy making ::: Findings throughout the different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: There are important limitations in decision analytic modeling that must be addressed. First, accurate modeling depends on several factors: a model structure that closely resembles reality, reasonable model assumptions, and relevant inputs. We acknowledge that not every possible scenario can be modeled and there may be important non-fatal outcomes that are relevant to cardiovascular patients that are inadequately represented. Another limitation is that models may be complex and difficult to understand without specialized knowledge or understanding of modeling software. To address concerns about model transparency, we believe such models should be public and to that end, we have provided a detailed supplemental appendix to describe the model structure and assumptions.
body_text.section: Limitations ::: Findings throughout the different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: Decision modelling is not designed to predict the future, but rather to provide decision makers with a credible envelope of possible scenarios. As witnessed in other jurisdictions, in a pandemic, failure to make anticipatory decisions can have dire consequences. Balanced against the direct impacts of the pandemic, delayed presentation and treatment of non-COVID 19 conditions, such as cardiac disease, result in significant sequelae; these spillover impacts are also critical consequences of the pandemic. The use of decision analytic modeling that is iterated on rapidly evolving data is a tool to help inform health policy decisions to address these difficult trade-offs.

FIGREF0.text: Figure 1: A schematic of the COVID-19 Resource Estimator (CORE) decision analytic model and the cardiac disease submodule that includes catheter based procedures (electrophysiology procedures, transcatheter aortic valve replacement, percutaneous coronary interventions) and open surgical procedures (coronary artery bypass grafting, valve surgery). Increasing numbers of COVID-19 patients and a steady number of elective cardiac outpatients compete for critical care resources. The stop sign denotes potential capacity constraints for resources. The model was adapted to measure incremental change in cardiac waitlist, consumption of critical care resources throughout the pandemic, and death while awaiting procedures for the entire province of Ontario and five geographical health regions using historic referral data, real time procedural data, and real time resource ICU and ward bed capacity data.

FIGREF1.text: Figure 2: Examples of different model outputs from the CORE model and cardiac submodule. A. Base case scenario for resource consumption by COVID-19 patients in Ontario based on what was known about COVID-19 epidemiology in late March (adapted from www.covid-19-mc.ca/). B. Estimated number of elective patient deaths over time with the cessation of elective cardiac procedures in early April followed by gradual resumption of procedures in mid-April to early May. C. The potential depletion of cardiac critical care resources if 75% of cardiac beds are reserved for COVID-19 patients and cardiac procedures are performed at 100% capacity. D. The predicted growth in waitlist as a consequence of holding all elective outpatient cardiac procedures for one week in April followed by gradual resumption of procedural activity.
